hints.content: Start by understanding what a substring is. A substring is a contiguous sequence of characters from a string. For example, in the string 'abc', the substrings of length 3 would be just 'abc'.
Remember that you need to find substrings of exactly length 3. This means you'll be looking at groups of three consecutive characters in the string.
Consider how you can iterate through the string to extract each substring of length 3. You can use a loop that goes from the start of the string to the third last character.
As you extract each substring, check if it contains distinct characters. You can do this by converting the substring to a set and comparing its length to 3.
Think about how to count the good substrings. You can maintain a counter that increments each time you find a substring with distinct characters.
Consider edge cases where the string length is less than 3. In these cases, you should return 0 since no substrings of length 3 can exist.
To check for distinct characters, you might want to use a set. A set automatically handles duplicates, so if the length of the set is 3, the substring has all distinct characters.
When iterating through the string, remember to only check substrings starting from index 0 to index length(s) - 3. This ensures you don't go out of bounds.
Make sure to handle multiple occurrences of the same good substring correctly. Each occurrence should be counted, so your loop should continue checking all possible substrings.
Finally, after counting all good substrings, return the count. Ensure your return statement is correctly placed after the loop that checks the substrings.

questionNotes: s consists of lowercase English letters.
Count every occurrence of good substrings, not just unique ones.
